Its substance is as valuable as its form is interesting and attractive. It introduces us to a distinguished circle os public men at Rome, who are represented as taking advantage of a more or less accidental gathering to discuss questions ol great interest and importance sor us as well as lor themselves. Meeting together in the calm repose which had resulted from the political settlement recently effected by the founder of the Flavian dynasty, they bring under review past and present circumstances in their bearing upon the profession in which they have all more or less a common interest, the profession of oratory,—exchanging opinions as to the merit and lame of the great orators ol republican times as well as the divergent tendencies of the spirit os their own day, comparing the main features of previous and contemporary methods of education,
